protected its currency.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence highlights a decisive response in a crisis, implying a tight monetary approach.\n    \n    \\item ``Forecast CPI at 1.89\\% supports growth.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a relatively low CPI, indicating that there is leeway for expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak orders for electronics and machinery may warrant supportive monetary steps.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence indicates that easing measures could be necessary to bolster export demand.\n    \n    \\item ``CBC maintained rates at 2.00\\% to ensure stability.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence provides a factual statement about unchanged interest rates without directional bias.\n\n    \\item ``The bank successively met with a total of 34 domestic banks between august 12 and august 21.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence describes a series of routine meetings with domestic banks and does not provide any indication of monetary stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of China}} \\label{tb:cbc_mp_stance_guide}\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & High rates to control inflation and reduce liquidity. & Lower rates to encourage borrowing and spending. & Rates remain unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy Stance} & Tightening measures such as reduced asset purchases or clear signals of future rate hikes. & Accommodative measures, including rate cuts, quantitative easing, or liquidity injections. & No significant change in policy stance or rates, indicating a wait-and-see approach. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Strong measures to keep CPI well below 2\\%. & Tolerance for higher inflation to support economic growth. & Inflation projections stable or within comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Historical Context} & Tightening responses in past crises. & Accommodative responses in past downturns. & Mentions of periods without major policy shifts. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth Forecasts} & Focus on curbing excessive expansion to mitigate inflation. & Policies that drive higher growth through domestic demand or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export levels with sustainable growth patterns. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Manufact-uring Activity} & Rapid output potentially causing input shortages or inflation pressures. & Decline in factory output due to weak global demand or disruptions. & Balanced output growth indicating stable demand in key markets. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Consumer Demand} & Rising domestic consumption pushing inflation beyond targets. & Weak household spending needing policy stimulus. & Stable consumer demand, supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the annual growth rate of the cpi was 1.97 in 2021, 2.95 in 2022, and 2.49  in 2023 and is projected by the bank to be 2.16 in 2024\n                "}]
2025-05-03 22:57:57,825 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence provides a factual statement about past and projected CPI growth rates without expressing a directional bias or indicating a specific monetary policy stance."
}

\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Strong measures to keep CPI well below 2\\%. & Tolerance for higher inflation to support economic growth. & Inflation projections stable or within comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Historical Context} & Tightening responses in past crises. & Accommodative responses in past downturns. & Mentions of periods without major policy shifts. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth Forecasts} & Focus on curbing excessive expansion to mitigate inflation. & Policies that drive higher growth through domestic demand or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export levels with sustainable growth patterns. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Manufact-uring Activity} & Rapid output potentially causing input shortages or inflation pressures. & Decline in factory output due to weak global demand or disruptions. & Balanced output growth indicating stable demand in key markets. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Consumer Demand} & Rising domestic consumption pushing inflation beyond targets. & Weak household spending needing policy stimulus. & Stable consumer demand, supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: one  board  director  stated  that  taiwan  is  currently  facing  greater  price-related  pressures  than  many  other  economies,  mainly  because  of  relatively  smaller  price  increases  in  oil  and  electricity  rates  in  the  past\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights Taiwan's current price-related pressures, implying a need for stricter inflation control, which is a hawkish stance."
}

Movements. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the central bank's set interest rates that influence borrowing costs and overall economic liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy Stance}: A sentence describing the direction and approach of the central bank's policy measures, including tightening or easing actions.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence relating to measures aimed at keeping consumer price inflation within target ranges to maintain price stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence addressing policies or indicators that reflect the growth of Taiwan's economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Stability}: A sentence related to the actions taken to maintain a stable value of the currency.\n    \\item \\emph{Historical Context}: A sentence providing reference to past monetary policy actions to historical situations.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth Forecasts}: A sentence discussing projected changes in the Gross Domestic Product, which is often used as an indicator of economic performance.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Expectations}: A sentence discussing inflation expectations, including actions or policy that would affect inflation expectations.\n    \\item \\emph{Export}: A sentence pertaining to the performance of a country’s exports and its implications on the economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Manufacturing Activity}: A sentence discussing manufacturing production, including metrics such as manufacturing output.\n    \\item \\emph{Consumer Demand}: A sentence describing the spending of households and its influence on the broader economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence relating to the fluctuations in prices of commodities such as raw materials and energy.\n    \\item \\emph{Credit Growth}: A sentence discussing the rate at which lending is fluctuating, indicating potential shifts in financial stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Movements}: A sentence addressing changes in the currency exchange rate.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``CBC focuses on price stability under 2\\%.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence signals that the central bank is committed to strict inflation control, implying a hawkish stance.\n    \n    \\item ``During the Asian Financial Crisis, Taiwan protected its currency.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence highlights a decisive response in a crisis, implying a tight monetary approach.\n    \n    \\item ``Forecast CPI at 1.89\\% supports growth.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a relatively low CPI, indicating that there is leeway for expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak orders for electronics and machinery may warrant supportive monetary steps.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence indicates that easing measures could be necessary to bolster export demand.\n    \n    \\item ``CBC supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: therefore, the bank expected to see private investment register  solid  real  growth  this  year\n                "}]

Growth, Exchange Rate Stability, Historical Context, GDP Growth Forecasts, Inflation Expectations, Export, Manufacturing Activity, Consumer Demand, Commodity Prices, Credit Growth, and Exchange Rate Movements. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the central bank's set interest rates that influence borrowing costs and overall economic liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy Stance}: A sentence describing the direction and approach of the central bank's policy measures, including tightening or easing actions.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence relating to measures aimed at keeping consumer price inflation within target ranges to maintain price stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence addressing policies or indicators that reflect the growth of Taiwan's economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Stability}: A sentence related to the actions taken to maintain a stable value of the currency.\n    \\item \\emph{Historical Context}: A sentence providing reference to past monetary policy actions to historical situations.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth Forecasts}: A sentence discussing projected changes in the Gross Domestic Product, which is often used as an indicator of economic performance.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Expectations}: A sentence discussing inflation expectations, including actions or policy that would affect inflation expectations.\n    \\item \\emph{Export}: A sentence pertaining to the performance of a country’s exports and its implications on the economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Manufacturing Activity}: A sentence discussing manufacturing production, including metrics such as manufacturing output.\n    \\item \\emph{Consumer Demand}: A sentence describing the spending of households and its influence on the broader economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence relating to the fluctuations in prices of commodities such as raw materials and energy.\n    \\item \\emph{Credit Growth}: A sentence discussing the rate at which lending is fluctuating, indicating potential shifts in financial stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Movements}: A sentence addressing changes in the currency exchange rate.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``CBC focuses on price stability under 2\\%.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence signals that the central bank is committed to strict inflation control, implying a hawkish stance.\n    \n    \\item ``During the Asian Financial Crisis, Taiwan protected its currency.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence highlights a decisive response in a crisis, implying a tight monetary approach.\n    \n    \\item ``Forecast CPI at 1.89\\% supports growth.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a relatively low CPI, indicating that there is leeway for expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak orders for electronics and machinery may warrant supportive monetary steps.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence indicates that easing measures could be necessary to bolster export demand.\n    \n    \\item ``CBC maintained rates at 2.00\\% to ensure stability.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence provides a factual statement about unchanged interest rates without directional bias.\n\n    \\item ``The bank successively met with a total of 34 domestic banks between august 12 and august 21.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence describes a series of routine meetings with domestic banks and does not provide any indication of monetary stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of China}} \\label{tb:cbc_mp_stance_guide}\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & High rates to control inflation and reduce liquidity. & Lower rates to encourage borrowing and spending. & Rates remain unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy Stance} & Tightening measures such as reduced asset purchases or clear signals of future rate hikes. & Accommodative measures, including rate cuts, quantitative easing, or liquidity injections. & No significant change in policy stance or rates, indicating a wait-and-see approach. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Strong measures to keep CPI well below 2\\%. & Tolerance for higher inflation to support economic growth. & Inflation projections stable or within comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Historical Context} & Tightening responses in past crises. & Accommodative responses in past downturns. & Mentions of periods without major policy shifts. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth Forecasts} & Focus on curbing excessive expansion to mitigate inflation. & Policies that drive higher growth through domestic demand or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbc}{fourteen} Interest Rates, Monetary Policy Stance, Inflation Control, Economic Growth, Exchange Rate Stability, Historical Context, GDP Growth Forecasts, Inflation Expectations, Export, Manufacturing Activity, Consumer Demand, Commodity Prices, Credit Growth, and Exchange Rate Movements. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the central bank's set interest rates that influence borrowing costs and overall economic liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy Stance}: A sentence describing the direction and approach of the central bank's policy measures, including tightening or easing actions.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence relating to measures aimed at keeping consumer price inflation within target ranges to maintain price stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence addressing policies or indicators that reflect the growth of Taiwan's economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Stability}: A sentence related to the actions taken to maintain a stable value of the currency.\n    \\item \\emph{Historical Context}: A sentence providing reference to past monetary policy actions to historical situations.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth Forecasts}: A sentence discussing projected changes in the Gross Domestic Product, which is often used as an indicator of economic performance.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Expectations}: A sentence discussing inflation expectations, including actions or policy that would affect inflation expectations.\n    \\item \\emph{Export}: A sentence pertaining to the performance of a country’s exports and its implications on the economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Manufacturing Activity}: A sentence discussing manufacturing production, including metrics such as manufacturing output.\n    \\item \\emph{Consumer Demand}: A sentence describing the spending of households and its influence on the broader economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence relating to the fluctuations in prices of commodities such as raw materials and energy.\n    \\item \\emph{Credit Growth}: A sentence discussing the rate at which lending is fluctuating, indicating potential shifts in financial stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Movements}: A sentence addressing changes in the currency exchange rate.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``CBC focuses on price stability under 2\\%.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence signals that the central bank is committed to strict inflation control, implying a hawkish stance.\n    \n    \\item ``During the Asian Financial Crisis, Taiwan protected its currency.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence highlights a decisive response in a crisis, implying a tight monetary approach.\n    \n    \\item ``Forecast CPI at 1.89\\% supports growth.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a relatively low CPI, indicating that there is leeway for expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak orders for electronics and machinery may warrant supportive monetary steps.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence indicates that easing measures could be necessary to bolster export demand.\n    \n    \\item ``CBC maintained rates at 2.00\\% to ensure stability.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence provides a factual statement about unchanged interest rates without directional bias.\n\n    \\item ``The bank successively met with a total of 34 domestic banks between august 12 and august 21.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence describes a series of routine meetings with domestic banks and does not provide any indication of monetary stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of China}} \\label{tb:cbc_mp_stance_guide}\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & High rates to control inflation and reduce liquidity. & Lower rates to encourage borrowing and spending. & Rates remain unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy Stance} & Tightening measures such as reduced asset purchases or clear signals of future rate hikes. & Accommodative measures, including rate cuts, quantitative easing, or liquidity injections. & No significant change in policy stance or rates, indicating a wait-and-see approach. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Strong measures to keep CPI well below 2\\%. & Tolerance for higher inflation to support economic growth. & Inflation projections stable or within comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Historical Context} & Tightening responses in past crises. & Accommodative responses in past downturns. & Mentions of periods without major policy shifts. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth Forecasts} & Focus on curbing excessive expansion to mitigate inflation. & Policies that drive higher growth through domestic demand or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export levels with sustainable growth patterns. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Manufact-uring Activity} & Rapid output potentially causing input shortages or inflation pressures. & Decline in factory output due to weak global demand or disruptions. & Balanced output growth indicating stable demand in key markets. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Consumer Demand} & Rising domestic consumption pushing inflation beyond targets. & Weak household spending needing policy stimulus. & Stable consumer demand, supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the construction loan  ratio of domestic banks was 26.84 at the end of october 2021, below the 30 cap prescribed  in article 72-2 of the banking act\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence provides a factual statement about the construction loan ratio of domestic banks, which does not indicate any stance on monetary policy."
}

\\item \\emph{Credit Growth}: A sentence discussing the rate at which lending is fluctuating, indicating potential shifts in financial stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Movements}: A sentence addressing changes in the currency exchange rate.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``CBC focuses on price stability under 2\\%.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence signals that the central bank is committed to strict inflation control, implying a hawkish stance.\n    \n    \\item ``During the Asian Financial Crisis, Taiwan protected its currency.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence highlights a decisive response in a crisis, implying a tight monetary approach.\n    \n    \\item ``Forecast CPI at 1.89\\% supports growth.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a relatively low CPI, indicating that there is leeway for expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak orders for electronics and machinery may warrant supportive monetary steps.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence indicates that easing measures could be necessary to bolster export demand.\n    \n    \\item ``CBC maintained rates at 2.00\\% to ensure stability.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence provides a factual statement about unchanged interest rates without directional bias.\n\n    \\item ``The bank successively met with a total of 34 domestic banks between august 12 and august 21.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence describes a series of routine meetings with domestic banks and does not provide any indication of monetary stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of China}} \\label{tb:cbc_mp_stance_guide}\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & High rates to control inflation and reduce liquidity. & Lower rates to encourage borrowing and spending. & Rates remain unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy Stance} & Tightening measures such as reduced asset purchases or clear signals of future rate hikes. & Accommodative measures, including rate cuts, quantitative easing, or liquidity injections. & No significant change in policy stance or rates, indicating a wait-and-see approach. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Strong measures to keep CPI well below 2\\%. & Tolerance for higher inflation to support economic growth. & Inflation projections stable or within comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Historical Context} & Tightening responses in past crises. & Accommodative responses in past downturns. & Mentions of periods without major policy shifts. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth Forecasts} & Focus on curbing excessive expansion to mitigate inflation. & Policies that drive higher growth through domestic demand or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export levels with sustainable growth patterns. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Manufact-uring Activity} & Rapid output potentially causing input shortages or inflation pressures. & Decline in factory output due to weak global demand or disruptions. & Balanced output growth indicating stable demand in key markets. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Consumer Demand} & Rising domestic consumption pushing inflation beyond targets. & Weak household spending needing policy stimulus. & Stable consumer demand, supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: monetary tightening measures have led to higher interest rates on bank deposits, loans, and money market instruments\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that monetary tightening measures have led to higher interest rates, implying a hawkish stance to control inflation and reduce liquidity."
}

comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Historical Context} & Tightening responses in past crises. & Accommodative responses in past downturns. & Mentions of periods without major policy shifts. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth Forecasts} & Focus on curbing excessive expansion to mitigate inflation. & Policies that drive higher growth through domestic demand or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export levels with sustainable growth patterns. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Manufact-uring Activity} & Rapid output potentially causing input shortages or inflation pressures. & Decline in factory output due to weak global demand or disruptions. & Balanced output growth indicating stable demand in key markets. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Consumer Demand} & Rising domestic consumption pushing inflation beyond targets. & Weak household spending needing policy stimulus. & Stable consumer demand, supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: among the subcategories, construction loans grew relatively faster year on year, mainly because construction firms acquired more land lots to meet potential property demand amid an influx of returning investments by overseas taiwanese businesses\n                "}]

Growth, Exchange Rate Stability, Historical Context, GDP Growth Forecasts, Inflation Expectations, Export, Manufacturing Activity, Consumer Demand, Commodity Prices, Credit Growth, and Exchange Rate Movements. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the central bank's set interest rates that influence borrowing costs and overall economic liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy Stance}: A sentence describing the direction and approach of the central bank's policy measures, including tightening or easing actions.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence relating to measures aimed at keeping consumer price inflation within target ranges to maintain price stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence addressing policies or indicators that reflect the growth of Taiwan's economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Stability}: A sentence related to the actions taken to maintain a stable value of the currency.\n    \\item \\emph{Historical Context}: A sentence providing reference to past monetary policy actions to historical situations.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth Forecasts}: A sentence discussing projected changes in the Gross Domestic Product, which is often used as an indicator of economic performance.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Expectations}: A sentence discussing inflation expectations, including actions or policy that would affect inflation expectations.\n    \\item \\emph{Export}: A sentence pertaining to the performance of a country’s exports and its implications on the economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Manufacturing Activity}: A sentence discussing manufacturing production, including metrics such as manufacturing output.\n    \\item \\emph{Consumer Demand}: A sentence describing the spending of households and its influence on the broader economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence relating to the fluctuations in prices of commodities such as raw materials and energy.\n    \\item \\emph{Credit Growth}: A sentence discussing the rate at which lending is fluctuating, indicating potential shifts in financial stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Movements}: A sentence addressing changes in the currency exchange rate.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``CBC focuses on price stability under 2\\%.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence signals that the central bank is committed to strict inflation control, implying a hawkish stance.\n    \n    \\item ``During the Asian Financial Crisis, Taiwan protected its currency.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence highlights a decisive response in a crisis, implying a tight monetary approach.\n    \n    \\item ``Forecast CPI at 1.89\\% supports growth.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a relatively low CPI, indicating that there is leeway for expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak orders for electronics and machinery may warrant supportive monetary steps.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence indicates that easing measures could be necessary to bolster export demand.\n    \n    \\item ``CBC maintained rates at 2.00\\% to ensure stability.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence provides a factual statement about unchanged interest rates without directional bias.\n\n    \\item ``The bank successively met with a total of 34 domestic banks between august 12 and august 21.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence describes a series of routine meetings with domestic banks and does not provide any indication of monetary stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of China}} Rates} & High rates to control inflation and reduce liquidity. & Lower rates to encourage borrowing and spending. & Rates remain unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ easing, or liquidity injections. & No significant change in policy stance or rates, indicating a wait-and-see approach. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nonetheless, major  companies remained cautious in devising investment strategies given the uncertainties  about  the  global  economic  outlook\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the cautious approach of major companies due to global economic uncertainties, but does not provide any indication of the central bank's monetary policy stance."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbc}{fourteen} Interest Rates, Monetary Policy Stance, Inflation Control, Economic Growth, Exchange Rate Stability, Historical Context, GDP Growth Forecasts, Inflation Expectations, Export, Manufacturing Activity, Consumer Demand, Commodity Prices, Credit Growth, and Exchange Rate Movements. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the central bank's set interest rates that influence borrowing costs and overall economic liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy Stance}: A sentence describing the direction and approach of the central bank's policy measures, including tightening or easing actions.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence relating to measures aimed at keeping consumer price inflation within target ranges to maintain price stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence addressing policies or indicators that reflect the growth of Taiwan's economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Stability}: A sentence related to the actions taken to maintain a stable value of the currency.\n    \\item \\emph{Historical Context}: A sentence providing reference to past monetary policy actions to historical situations.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth Forecasts}: A sentence discussing projected changes in the Gross Domestic Product, which is often used as an indicator of economic performance.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Expectations}: A sentence discussing inflation expectations, including actions or policy that would affect inflation expectations.\n    \\item \\emph{Export}: A sentence pertaining to the performance of a country’s exports and its implications on the economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Manufacturing Activity}: A sentence discussing manufacturing production, including metrics such as manufacturing output.\n    \\item \\emph{Consumer Demand}: A sentence describing the spending of households and its influence on the broader economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence relating to the fluctuations in prices of commodities such as raw materials and energy.\n    \\item \\emph{Credit Growth}: A sentence discussing the rate at which lending is fluctuating, indicating potential shifts in financial stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Movements}: A sentence addressing changes in the currency exchange rate.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``CBC focuses on price stability under 2\\%.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence signals that the central bank is committed to strict inflation control, implying a hawkish stance.\n    \n    \\item ``During the Asian Financial Crisis, Taiwan protected its currency.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence highlights a decisive response in a crisis, implying a tight monetary approach.\n    \n    \\item ``Forecast CPI at 1.89\\% supports growth.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a relatively low CPI, indicating that there is leeway for expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak orders for electronics and machinery may warrant supportive monetary steps.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence indicates that easing measures could be necessary to bolster export demand.\n    \n    \\item ``CBC maintained rates at 2.00\\% to ensure stability.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence provides a factual statement about unchanged interest rates without directional bias.\n\n    \\item ``The bank successively met with a total of 34 domestic banks between august 12 and august 21.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence describes a series of routine meetings with domestic banks and does not provide any indication of monetary stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of China}} \\label{tb:cbc_mp_stance_guide}\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & High rates to control inflation and reduce liquidity. & Lower rates to encourage borrowing and spending. & Rates remain unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy Stance} & Tightening measures such as reduced asset purchases or clear signals of future rate hikes. & Accommodative measures, including rate cuts, quantitative easing, or liquidity injections. & No significant change in policy stance or rates, indicating a wait-and-see approach. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Strong measures to keep CPI well below 2\\%. & Tolerance for higher inflation to support economic growth. & Inflation projections stable or within comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Historical Context} & Tightening responses in past crises. & Accommodative responses in past downturns. & Mentions of periods without major policy shifts. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth Forecasts} & Focus on curbing excessive expansion to mitigate inflation. & Policies that drive higher growth through domestic demand or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export levels with sustainable growth patterns. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Manufact-uring Activity} & Rapid output potentially causing input shortages or inflation pressures. & Decline in factory output due to weak global demand or disruptions. & Balanced output growth indicating stable demand in key markets. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Consumer Demand} & Rising domestic consumption pushing inflation beyond targets. & Weak household spending needing policy stimulus. & Stable consumer demand, supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: with the interest rates already at a relatively lower level, the future policy space will be limited\n                "}]

Movements. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the central bank's set interest rates that influence borrowing costs and overall economic liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy Stance}: A sentence describing the direction and approach of the central bank's policy measures, including tightening or easing actions.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence relating to measures aimed at keeping consumer price inflation within target ranges to maintain price stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence addressing policies or indicators that reflect the growth of Taiwan's economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Stability}: A sentence related to the actions taken to maintain a stable value of the currency.\n    \\item \\emph{Historical Context}: A sentence providing reference to past monetary policy actions to historical situations.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth Forecasts}: A sentence discussing projected changes in the Gross Domestic Product, which is often used as an indicator of economic performance.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Expectations}: A sentence discussing inflation expectations, including actions or policy that would affect inflation expectations.\n    \\item \\emph{Export}: A sentence pertaining to the performance of a country’s exports and its implications on the economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Manufacturing Activity}: A sentence discussing manufacturing production, including metrics such as manufacturing output.\n    \\item \\emph{Consumer Demand}: A sentence describing the spending of households and its influence on the broader economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence relating to the fluctuations in prices of commodities such as raw materials and energy.\n    \\item \\emph{Credit Growth}: A sentence discussing the rate at which lending is fluctuating, indicating potential shifts in financial stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Movements}: A sentence addressing changes in the currency exchange rate.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``CBC focuses on price stability under 2\\%.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence signals that the central bank is committed to strict inflation control, implying a hawkish stance.\n    \n    \\item ``During the Asian Financial Crisis, Taiwan protected its currency.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence highlights a decisive response in a crisis, implying a tight monetary approach.\n    \n    \\item ``Forecast CPI at 1.89\\% supports growth.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a relatively low CPI, indicating that there is leeway for expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak orders for electronics and machinery may warrant supportive monetary steps.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence indicates that easing measures could be necessary to bolster export demand.\n    \n    \\item ``CBC maintained rates at 2.00\\% to ensure stability.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence provides a factual statement about unchanged interest rates without directional bias.\n\n    \\item ``The bank successively met with a total of 34 domestic banks between august 12 and august 21.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence describes a series of routine meetings with domestic banks and does not provide any indication of monetary stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of China}} \\label{tb:cbc_mp_stance_guide}\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & High rates to control inflation and reduce liquidity. & Lower rates to encourage borrowing and spending. & Rates remain unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy Stance} & Tightening measures such as reduced asset purchases or clear signals of future rate hikes. & Accommodative measures, including rate cuts, quantitative easing, or liquidity injections. & No significant change in policy stance or rates, indicating a wait-and-see approach. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Strong measures to keep CPI well below 2\\%. & Tolerance for higher inflation to support economic growth. & Inflation projections stable or within comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Historical Context} & Tightening responses in past crises. & Accommodative responses in past downturns. & Mentions of periods without major policy shifts. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth Forecasts} & Focus on curbing excessive expansion to mitigate inflation. & Policies that drive higher growth through domestic demand or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export levels with sustainable growth patterns. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Manufact-uring Activity} & Rapid output potentially causing input shortages or inflation pressures. & Decline in factory output due to weak global demand or disruptions. & Balanced output growth indicating stable demand in key markets. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Consumer Demand} & Rising domestic consumption pushing inflation beyond targets. & Weak household spending needing policy stimulus. & Stable consumer demand, supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the cbc has adopted consistent exchange rate policy aimed at dynamic stability\n                "}]

bank successively met with a total of 34 domestic banks between august 12 and august 21.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence describes a series of routine meetings with domestic banks and does not provide any indication of monetary stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of China}} \\label{tb:cbc_mp_stance_guide}\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & High rates to control inflation and reduce liquidity. & Lower rates to encourage borrowing and spending. & Rates remain unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy Stance} & Tightening measures such as reduced asset purchases or clear signals of future rate hikes. & Accommodative measures, including rate cuts, quantitative easing, or liquidity injections. & No significant change in policy stance or rates, indicating a wait-and-see approach. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Strong measures to keep CPI well below 2\\%. & Tolerance for higher inflation to support economic growth. & Inflation projections stable or within comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Historical Context} & Tightening responses in past crises. & Accommodative responses in past downturns. & Mentions of periods without major policy shifts. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth Forecasts} & Focus on curbing excessive expansion to mitigate inflation. & Policies that drive higher growth through domestic demand or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export levels with sustainable growth patterns. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Manufact-uring Activity} & Rapid output potentially causing input shortages or inflation pressures. & Decline in factory output due to weak global demand or disruptions. & Balanced output growth indicating stable demand in key markets. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Consumer Demand} & Rising domestic consumption pushing inflation beyond targets. & Weak household spending needing policy stimulus. & Stable consumer demand, supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in terms of the inflation outlook for the second half of the year, the recent cigarette tax hike may exert upward pressures on prices\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that the cigarette tax hike may lead to upward pressures on prices, implying a potential inflationary risk that may warrant a hawkish response from the central bank."

\\item \\emph{Monetary Policy Stance}: A sentence describing the direction and approach of the central bank's policy measures, including tightening or easing actions.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence relating to measures aimed at keeping consumer price inflation within target ranges to maintain price stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence addressing policies or indicators that reflect the growth of Taiwan's economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Stability}: A sentence related to the actions taken to maintain a stable value of the currency.\n changes in the Gross Domestic Product, which is often used as an indicator of economic performance.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Expectations}: A sentence discussing inflation expectations, including actions or policy that would affect inflation expectations.\n    \\item \\emph{Export}: A sentence pertaining to the performance of a country’s exports and its implications on the economy.\n    \\item sentence addressing changes in the currency exchange rate.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``CBC focuses on price stability under 2\\%.''\\\\\n or exports. & Stable projections indicating moderate, sustainable growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Expectations} & Very strict control near 2\\% or lower to avoid price instability. & Willingness to let inflation rise slightly if beneficial for growth. & Projections remain moderate and steady. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Export} & Robust export growth, risking overheating and trade imbalances. & Declining export demand, suggesting easing measures to support exporters. & Stable export levels with sustainable growth patterns. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Manufact-uring Activity} & Rapid output potentially causing input shortages or inflation pressures. & Decline in factory output due to weak global demand or disruptions. & Balanced output growth indicating stable demand in key markets. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Consumer Demand} & Rising domestic consumption pushing inflation beyond targets. & Weak household spending needing policy stimulus. & Stable consumer demand, supporting GDP without driving up inflation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & Rising global commodity costs (energy, raw materials) pressuring margins. & Falling import prices easing inflation and supporting growth. & Stable commodity prices reducing uncertainty in production and exports. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit Growth} & Rapid credit expansion increasing leverage and financial instability risks. & Slowing credit growth indicating tight conditions, possibly needing easing. & Moderate credit growth aligned with economic needs (e.g., SMEs). & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Movements} & NTD appreciation, harming exports and requiring tighter interventions. & NTD depreciation, helping exports but risking imported inflation. & Stable rates ensuring balanced trade flows with minimal inflation pressure. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: several  board  directors  also  expressed  concern  about  the  situation  where  a  borrower  inherits  a  housing  property  with  an  outstanding  loan but has to take out the second loan to buy a home because of job-related relocation,  subjecting the borrower to the new stricter credit controls of no grace period and lower  ltv ratios\n                "}]

Growth, Exchange Rate Stability, Historical Context, GDP Growth Forecasts, Inflation Expectations, Export, Manufacturing Activity, Consumer Demand, Commodity Prices, Credit Growth, and Exchange Rate Movements. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the central bank's set interest rates that influence borrowing costs and overall economic liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy Stance}: A sentence describing the direction and approach of the central bank's policy measures, including tightening or easing actions.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence relating to measures aimed at keeping consumer price inflation within target ranges to maintain price stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence addressing policies or indicators that reflect the growth of Taiwan's economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Stability}: A sentence related to the actions taken to maintain a stable value of the currency.\n    \\item \\emph{Historical Context}: A sentence providing reference to past monetary policy actions to historical situations.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth Forecasts}: A sentence discussing projected changes in the Gross Domestic Product, which is often used as an indicator of economic performance.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Expectations}: A sentence discussing inflation expectations, including actions or policy that would affect inflation expectations.\n    \\item \\emph{Export}: A sentence pertaining to the performance of a country’s exports and its implications on the economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Manufacturing Activity}: A sentence discussing manufacturing production, including metrics such as manufacturing output.\n    \\item \\emph{Consumer Demand}: A sentence describing the spending of households and its influence on the broader economy.\n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence relating to the fluctuations in prices of commodities such as raw materials and energy.\n    \\item \\emph{Credit Growth}: A sentence discussing the rate at which lending is fluctuating, indicating potential shifts in financial stability.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Movements}: A sentence addressing changes in the currency exchange rate.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``CBC focuses on price stability under 2\\%.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence signals that the central bank is committed to strict inflation control, implying a hawkish stance.\n    \n    \\item ``During the Asian Financial Crisis, Taiwan protected its currency.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence highlights a decisive response in a crisis, implying a tight monetary approach.\n    \n    \\item ``Forecast CPI at 1.89\\% supports growth.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence suggests a relatively low CPI, indicating that there is leeway for expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak orders for electronics and machinery may warrant supportive monetary steps.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence indicates that easing measures could be necessary to bolster export demand.\n    \n    \\item ``CBC maintained rates at 2.00\\% to ensure stability.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence provides a factual statement about unchanged interest rates without directional bias.\n\n    \\item ``The bank successively met with a total of 34 domestic banks between august 12 and august 21.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence describes a series of routine meetings with domestic banks and does not provide any indication of monetary stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of China}} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & High rates to control inflation and reduce liquidity. & Lower rates to encourage borrowing and spending. & Rates remain unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy Stance} & Tightening measures such as reduced asset purchases or clear signals of future rate hikes. & Accommodative measures, including rate cuts, quantitative easing, or liquidity injections. & No significant change in policy stance or rates, indicating a wait-and-see approach. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Strong measures to keep CPI well below 2\\%. & Tolerance for higher inflation to support economic growth. & Inflation projections stable or within comfortable bounds. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & Policies to prevent overheating. & Measures to stimulate growth (e.g., rate cuts). & Balanced approach to growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ \n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Stability} & Aggressive forex interventions to stabilize or strengthen the currency. & Allowing slight depreciation to boost exports; looser approach to FX. & Stable exchange rates are maintained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\ "label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that inflation rates are expected to ease to below 2% next year, indicating a dovish stance as it implies a relatively low inflation environment that may warrant accommodative monetary policy."
}
